And I think, I think we've even talked about, and maybe this is a sidebar, but I think we've talked about in the past how sometimes in our sin, women tend to want control anyway, and men tend towards passivity, like in general. And so even from just a healthy practice, I think that's a good conversation to have when it comes to women in ministry. Like what is this encouraging? Not that women are not capable, but what is it encouraging for that specific situation? But yeah, but I think even, I think it takes a lot of humility and a lot of coming to scripture and, and even as a woman who has some leadership role of making sure that, that I am still respecting men and I'm engaging with them in a way that, that is honoring to them. And I don't know, I think it's, I think it's complicated. It is. But as with any leadership role, I think humility and deference to scripture is, is key. And that's, here's what's cool. That well, you said key, that's exactly right. That is a much better measure of where someone is in their walk with Christ than their stance on the role of women in ministry. And so I do believe you can be a great student of scripture. You could be a good student, a great student of scripture and come to the conclusion that's different than my personal conclusion on this. All the way to women should have essentially no role of leadership in teaching in the church to women can have almost any role of leadership in teaching in the church. But here's what, when I, when I've thought about this before, I've known if, if I was talking to a woman seeking to work at the church and she was dogmatically fighting for her rights to lead in the church, I would know there's an immaturity there. In the same way, if I hired a man who was dogmatically principled, the fact that women could not have any role of leadership in the church, I would know there's an immaturity there. He may believe that, or she may believe that, but it's wild how often we will ignore the clear teaching of being a good neighbor, of being kind, of being soft hearted, of being gentle. We'll ignore those because those are only commanded like 4,000 times in the New Testament in order to fight about a topic that is authentically not clear. And even me saying that, there are probably people listening who would scream at the mic and be like, it is clear. I get that. I get why it's clear to you. I understand that. I do not think it is hermeneutically clear. And so I think we have to come at those humbly. And even more, like even a step further on that is if someone is fighting for themselves specifically to be in leadership. So not only their stance and what they believe, but if someone is like, I need to be in a role of leadership, whether or not they're a man or a woman, like asking the heart question of like, okay, what is the motive behind that? Is that saying whether or not you can defend what you believe scripturally, like what is that saying about the state of your heart that you think instead of like, hey, God's given me these gifts or I feel like I have, you know, he's given me an opportunity to lead or serve instead of saying like, I need to be in leadership. What is that saying about you? That's a great point. It reminded me to clarify if whatever the Bible is teaching about this, it's doing it in terms of roles and responsibilities, not in terms of value or even abilities. And so it doesn't, there's nothing that the Bible is saying that women are somehow genetically or at a gender level, less capable of leading or teaching. That is not, that's nowhere in scripture. The question would be, is it appropriate, is it most appropriate for them to be in positions of leadership or teaching in the local church? And that's the question is being debated. It should never be the value of women or men or the comparative, I don't know, giftings of men, women and capabilities. Like those should not be in the discussion. And I also sometimes hear people abuse this concept from a concept of submission in that women are not in submission to men. And we talked about this in the podcast. It's clearly in the passage, there is a role of women being submitted to their husbands and husbands sacrificing everything for their wives. I am not responsible to sacrifice for every woman. And not every woman is responsible to submit to me. That's not how that works. It's not a sex based description there in those passages. But it gets extrapolated incorrectly. Yeah. Okay. And I think part of that is, I think there is a general wisdom. We see this in God. God does it all through the Old Testament a lot where he's teaching a general principle by requiring certain things of his people. It isn't that he thinks it's morally, you know, did God think it was morally wrong to eat meat and cheese together? Like I don't know that God thought that was morally wrong. He was teaching a lesson to his people. Some things are clean and some things are this and some things are that and you don't mix them. And it's a vitally important lesson is as the church, if we don't have these conversations, I think we may miss out on, okay, what is God trying to teach us? Is he teaching us that you don't ever, not every males and females have to have the same roles to be equally valuable. And so that needs to be modeled by the church. It's okay if men and women have different roles in the church that does not communicate different value. It just communicates different roles. And is that something he's trying to teach it? It's certainly something we need to wrestle through is can I be just as valuable if I'm not a woman or can I be just as valuable if I'm not a man? And our temptation is to go, well, I'm not just as valuable because I can't serve in whatever role this is. Like, no, that's not an issue of value. That's just an issue of roles. And that's an important lesson for us to catch and to continue to hold fast to even if we disagree about what roles are okay and not okay, that we hold fast to this idea. Your roles are not what give you value or identity, God forbid. That's right. Exactly right. And we're stuck in that right now, where in order to be equally valuable, we all have to have the same outcomes and the same roles and the same positions. And that is not a biblical picture. That's just kind of broken. So anyway, there you go. That's great. Okay. Well, that's dealt with those first two. Yeah, that's awesome. And I think we'll have some more. I think this is the first of probably at least a couple of question and response episodes. Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. We'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.

Okay, so there's depth to this question.
So thank you, thank you, listener.
I actually don't have it written down who sent that, but thank you for being willing
to ask a hard question.
We never want to shy away from those.
Bryn, do you want to go to the next one?
The next one is, in light of recent podcasts surrounding sexism in the Bible, what exactly
does the Bible say or not say regarding women pastors?
Is Rick Warren correct?
It is biblical to have a female pastor.
Why are we not?
Can pastors only be men?
Why are we not?
Very light.
And that one was in light of Rick Warren made a comment at the Southern Baptist Convention
that was then knocked down.
And so, I don't...
So this one, if we stay with it narrowly, because we did have all those, I would tell you somebody,
if you're going to listen to this answer, if you've not listened to the podcast on sexism
under this season of Is the Bible Immoral by Today Standards, please go do so.
That would be helpful.
Yeah, I think that would be really helpful.
This is picking on a very specific word.
The specific word here is pastor.
And the answer to this question is going to depend on how you define the word pastor.
And what so many people don't know is that this is not a simple word within the evangelical
church.
The word pastor means a lot of different things to a lot of different people.
And so, it very much so depends on how you define the word.
And I am, because of my background and what I've done in my own Bible study, I do not
define the word...
I personally, this is a personal statement, I don't define the word pastor as being a
title within the church, as in like an officer within the church, something that Christ or
Paul or John established as a position within the church.
The word pastor literally means shepherd.
It's a Greek word that comes from the poemon, meaning...
No, not poemon.
Shoot, I'll look it up real quick.
You're fine.
Okay.
Oh, it is poemon.
All that.
And I was right from the beginning.
I'm smarter than I thought.
Okay.
So this word is where we get the word pastor, and it just means shepherd.
It doesn't have another meaning.
Now what's happened over the years, it's pastor has become a job title.
It doesn't just mean shepherd to a lot of people.
Now what it means is the person who is the top dog at the church, the big cheese.
It is the lead pastor, the senior pastor, or, so that's one, or it means someone who
teaches.
So pastors teach.
When we go to Timothy, first, second Timothy and Titus, when it lists the role, the two
offices that Paul does create, which are Deacon and Elder.
Sorry.
And so Deacon and Elder.
And in those, you get this very complicated, which we went over in the podcast, this very
complicated conversation about the phrase husband of one wife.
Does that mean it can only be men can have these roles?
That is complicated by Paul in Romans 16, referencing a woman who is a Deacon.
And so she's clearly not the husband of one wife.
And it is, so then, then what does that, did that mean Paul didn't mean for it to be only
men, only husbands?
Can single people be Deacons?
Is it, is it a, does it just mean you can't be a polygamist and be a Deacon?
Like you can't be having an affair, you have to be faithful to your, and so people have
debated about that for 2000 years as to exactly who that applies to and doesn't apply to.
And people will be until Christ comes back or, or he sends Paul back to add an addendum
or something like that to clear that up for us.
And that same phrase is used with elder.
Now what we don't have is in a female version of an elder anywhere in the New Testament.
And so the, a common evangelical view is that women might can be Deacons.
Some would say no, some would say not.
That's a little more generally accepted.
And then you would have, and lots of churches would say no, women cannot serve as Deacons.
And then more, even more churches say women can't serve as elders because there's not
a female example of an elder.
So there's, I know this is a little convoluted, but I'm putting the pieces together for you.
I'm tracking.
I'm tracking.
Okay.
Yeah.
So if I'm tracking, I feel like most everyone.
Exactly.
And so the, the elder role is the one that calls for someone to be able to handle the
word of God.
So a teacher.
So elders have to be capable of teaching the word.
That's one of their responsibilities.
Now you put two and two together and you get 46, 47.
And so you get their teachers who are their elders.
Hey, pastors, typically they're in roles of teaching.
Therefore you have this integration of the role of elder and pastor.
When they're integrated as they are in a lot of churches.
Whoa.
When they're integrated.
You must date.
Okay.
Picking that back up.
When they're integrated together, the pastor concept of the pastor as a teacher and the
concept of the elder as the teacher, then what you say is elders and pastors are essentially
the same thing.
And therefore if women can be elders, then women can't be pastors.
Now that's obviously a pretty convoluted path to take to get to that conclusion.
But there are many in the evangelical church who would take that path.
So my personal opinion, just for a second, I personally, because I don't see any place
in the Bible that actually makes that connection for us, I would say, well, I think a woman
could have the title pastor.
The question would be, is it appropriate for a woman to be the lead point person in a church,
in a local body, or is it appropriate to have a woman teaching in a general sense in the
church?
What would be the most difficult conversations to have?
Is it appropriate given what Paul teaches about the early church for a woman to be the
point person, the lead person in a church?
And that's a different conversation than saying, could she have the job title pastor, meaning
shepherd?
And so what's fascinating is you could easily give almost any woman in any evangelical church
the job title shepherd.
And no one would say a word.
I've even jokingly said I was going to give a woman the job title poiman.
So literally literally literally pastor and yet and so see if anyone says anything.
But I think I think the question here is a question within Christianity and within the
local church is a question of the heart and submission.
Are we, for example, there's a woman on our staff who I would have given her the job title
pastor.
And she said, I'm uncomfortable with that because I think people will think I'm not
submissive to the convention or to the teaching in general of the church or whatever.
And so I'm not comfortable with that.
And I said, well, one of us is going to have to explain things.
Either I'm going to have to explain to people why you don't have the title pastor, or you're
going to have to explain to people why you do.
So I'll be the one who does the explaining.
I will defer to you.
So her title says director.
Now, would there have been people who might have left the church over that?
Yeah, sure.
That might have happened.
I could have explained it.
I feel like I can explain it.
Well, I'm not claiming that this person is an elder.
I'm not claiming that this person is the point person in the church.
I understand why those two are what things are two topics people are willing to really
engage with.
So the question is, is Rick Warren corrected at the bit is biblical that a female pastor?
Well, that would depend on how Rick Warren was defining the word pastor.
And so now it may be that even if he's defining the word pastor as a woman could be the lead
elder in a church, he might still be right, though that's much harder to defend.
And I think there are plenty of people who would be okay with it and plenty of people
would not be okay with it.
And I'm not taking a stance here for me, and I'm certainly not for the church.
We do have women who are who serve as leaders in our church.
We have women who have men under them and employee.
We have women who teach classes alongside their husbands that have men and women in
the class.
And so we've wrestled through these passages and in the dynamic and uncomfortable tension
of what the New Testament teaches about these things.
This is kind of the path we're walking.
But I certainly respect the fact I was an elder at a church before this that would not
have allowed any of that.
And I don't think they're wrong.
And I'm not saying we're right and they're wrong or they're right and we're wrong where
we are here.
What I would say is this conversation has a pretty broad.
Your hermeneutic can be very good.
And yet you come to a pretty broad conclusion as to where what is the appropriate role of
women in church.
But it is hard.
I mean, I'm curious to hear some Brin's thoughts on this too.
It's hard.
I feel like there is a, and maybe I'm overstating it to say it's hard to be a woman in church
or maybe it's hard to be a woman in, I don't know what the right law to say it.
So how would you say that?
Step in church.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And I think some of it is even like you're saying a heart conversation of regardless
of whether or not they can have the title, like, is it even like, what is it communicating
the church body for that specific church body for that role?
And you know, is, is it encouraging men to step up and leave their families?
And you know, like all those conversations, um, because that is pretty clear scripturally,
right?
It's supposed to have a role of leadership in their family.
Right.
And I think, I think we've even talked about, and maybe this is a sidebar, but I think we've
talked about in the past how sometimes in our sin, women tend to want control anyway,
and men tend towards passivity, like in general.
And so even from just a healthy practice, I think that's a good conversation to have
when it comes to women in ministry.
Like what is this encouraging?
Not that women are not capable, but what is it encouraging for that specific situation?
But yeah, but I think even, I think it takes a lot of humility and a lot of coming to scripture
and, and even as a woman who has some leadership role of making sure that, that I am still
respecting men and I'm engaging with them in a way that, that is honoring to them.
And I don't know, I think it's, I think it's complicated.
It is.
But as with any leadership role, I think humility and deference to scripture is, is key.
And that's, here's what's cool.
That well, you said key, that's exactly right.
That is a much better measure of where someone is in their walk with Christ than their stance
on the role of women in ministry.
And so I do believe you can be a great student of scripture.
You could be a good student, a great student of scripture and come to the conclusion that's
different than my personal conclusion on this.
All the way to women should have essentially no role of leadership in teaching in the church
to women can have almost any role of leadership in teaching in the church.
But here's what, when I, when I've thought about this before, I've known if, if I was
talking to a woman seeking to work at the church and she was dogmatically fighting for
her rights to lead in the church, I would know there's an immaturity there.
In the same way, if I hired a man who was dogmatically principled, the fact that women
could not have any role of leadership in the church, I would know there's an immaturity
there.
He may believe that, or she may believe that, but it's wild how often we will ignore the
clear teaching of being a good neighbor, of being kind, of being soft hearted, of being
gentle.
We'll ignore those because those are only commanded like 4,000 times in the New Testament
in order to fight about a topic that is authentically not clear.
And even me saying that, there are probably people listening who would scream at the mic
and be like, it is clear.
I get that.
I get why it's clear to you.
I understand that.
I do not think it is hermeneutically clear.
And so I think we have to come at those humbly.
And even more, like even a step further on that is if someone is fighting for themselves
specifically to be in leadership.
So not only their stance and what they believe, but if someone is like, I need to be in a
role of leadership, whether or not they're a man or a woman, like asking the heart question
of like, okay, what is the motive behind that?
Is that saying whether or not you can defend what you believe scripturally, like what is
that saying about the state of your heart that you think instead of like, hey, God's
given me these gifts or I feel like I have, you know, he's given me an opportunity to
lead or serve instead of saying like, I need to be in leadership.
What is that saying about you?
That's a great point.
It reminded me to clarify if whatever the Bible is teaching about this, it's doing it
in terms of roles and responsibilities, not in terms of value or even abilities.
And so it doesn't, there's nothing that the Bible is saying that women are somehow genetically
or at a gender level, less capable of leading or teaching.
That is not, that's nowhere in scripture.
The question would be, is it appropriate, is it most appropriate for them to be in positions
of leadership or teaching in the local church?
And that's the question is being debated.
It should never be the value of women or men or the comparative, I don't know, giftings
of men, women and capabilities.
Like those should not be in the discussion.
And I also sometimes hear people abuse this concept from a concept of submission in that
women are not in submission to men.
And we talked about this in the podcast.
It's clearly in the passage, there is a role of women being submitted to their husbands
and husbands sacrificing everything for their wives.
I am not responsible to sacrifice for every woman.
And not every woman is responsible to submit to me.
That's not how that works.
It's not a sex based description there in those passages.
But it gets extrapolated incorrectly.
Yeah.
Okay.
And I think part of that is, I think there is a general wisdom.
We see this in God.
God does it all through the Old Testament a lot where he's teaching a general principle
by requiring certain things of his people.
It isn't that he thinks it's morally, you know, did God think it was morally wrong to
eat meat and cheese together?
Like I don't know that God thought that was morally wrong.
He was teaching a lesson to his people.
Some things are clean and some things are this and some things are that and you don't
mix them.
And it's a vitally important lesson is as the church, if we don't have these conversations,
I think we may miss out on, okay, what is God trying to teach us?
Is he teaching us that you don't ever, not every males and females have to have the same
roles to be equally valuable.
And so that needs to be modeled by the church.
It's okay if men and women have different roles in the church that does not communicate
different value.
It just communicates different roles.
And is that something he's trying to teach it?
It's certainly something we need to wrestle through is can I be just as valuable if I'm
not a woman or can I be just as valuable if I'm not a man?
And our temptation is to go, well, I'm not just as valuable because I can't serve in
whatever role this is.
Like, no, that's not an issue of value.
That's just an issue of roles.
And that's an important lesson for us to catch and to continue to hold fast to even if we
disagree about what roles are okay and not okay, that we hold fast to this idea.
Your roles are not what give you value or identity, God forbid.
That's right.
Exactly right.
And we're stuck in that right now, where in order to be equally valuable, we all have
to have the same outcomes and the same roles and the same positions.
And that is not a biblical picture.
That's just kind of broken.
So anyway, there you go.
That's great.
Okay.
Well, that's dealt with those first two.
Yeah, that's awesome.
And I think we'll have some more.
I think this is the first of probably at least a couple of question and response episodes.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
We'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info

Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
